We model the situation as a random variable $X \sim B(3,\frac{2}{3})$. Then $\Pr(H_2 \mid H_1) = \frac{\Pr(X=2) + \Pr(X=3)}{\sum_{1 \le i \le 3}{\Pr(X=i)}}$. Then finally $\Pr = \frac{\binom{3}{2}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^2\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) + \binom{3}{3}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^3}{\sum_{1 \le i \le 3}{\binom{3}{i}\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^i\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{3-i}}} = \frac{10}{13}$(b) $\Pr(X=1 | H_1) = 1-\frac{10}{13} = \frac{3}{13}$ 5:(a) $\Pr = \frac{n-1}{365}$. To see this, note that the probability that a given student has the same birthday as me is $\frac{1}{365}$; so the probability that at least one of $n$ students is simply a summation of this probability.(b) For $\Pr \ge \frac{1}{2}$, we need $n \ge 184$.(c) The problem differs from the birthday problem in that we care about a specific date (my birthday) and matching to it: in the birthday problem, we consider all pairs of dates and seek any match, not just a particular one.6:(a) $p_1 = 0$, since we must roll at least twice. Next, note that all $p_r$ are mutually exclusive. Finally, note that for $i \gt 7$, $p_i = 0$, for to roll 7 times without seeing a repeat, we'd have a set of rolls $R$ with magnitude $7 \gt 6$ (the number of possible rolls). Therefore, the 7th roll is always a repeat.Then we are interested in $p_i, 2 \le i \le 7$. Of course, $p_2 = \frac{1}{6}$. Then $p_3$ occurs iff $p_2$ does not, and iff we roll either of our first two rolls: $p_3 = \frac{5}{6}\left(\frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{6}\right) = \frac{5}{18}$.
